Los Angeles investors buy apartment buildings in rundown neighborhoods, then they fix them up.
They set aside at least one unit as a tutoring center and staff it with a qualified teacher.
They've watched vacancy rates and maintenance costs drop and profits begin to climb.
Robin Urevich went to South Los Angeles to check it out.
Landlord Joe Killinger pulls his black Mercedes up to one of his South L.A.
apartments.
It's a typical two-storey stucco in a part of town known as The Jungle.
We own this building right here, 4066 and then 4052 Coco Avenue, right here.
It's clean and quiet now, but three years ago, Killinger says, it was so dangerous here that children couldn't even play inside the apartment gates.
Unidentified Woman #1: Two times nine.
Unidentified Woman #2: Eighteen.
Unidentified Woman #1: You remembered that one.
Now kids like third grader Chelsea Downs play in the courtyard, and they can go inside to get help with homework in this one-bedroom apartment turned learning center.
I'm trying to make my grades higher.
Like everything, like language arts, math and stuff, I want to make those fours and not twos and threes.
The buildings' owners, Joe Killinger and George Pino, are commercial realtors who came up with the tutoring center idea more than three years ago.
They figured that in a 50-unit complex they could take one unit off the market and offer another rent-free to a certified teacher.
They'd lose income but they bet the center would pay for itself because tenants would stay longer and take more pride in their apartments.
They found the right building and bought with co-investor Alan Long.
We really felt that it would - instead of having a 20 percent vacancy, we'd have a waiting list.
Instead of people not paying their rent on time, they were paying their rent on time.

Instead of them not stealing everything that's not screwed down, they were actually calling us and letting us know that, you know, somebody's out there doing graffiti or they caught some kids trying to put graffiti on the side of the building.
Three years later, Long, who now heads Sotheby's International Realty in L.A., says they were right.
No vacancies and low maintenance costs have yielded big profits.
We're making 18 percent per year on our money.
So we're making three-times the amount of money you would make in a bank, and most likely these buildings that we bought will be worth double in tens years what we paid for them.
Now they own a total of five buildings where two learning centers serve about a hundred low-income families.
Rents are among the lowest in L.A.
- around $950 for a two-bedroom apartment.
George Pino says he and his partner didn't start out as socially responsible investors.
They bought their first South L.A.
building 11 years ago for one reason.
All Joe and I could afford was low-income neighborhoods.
And we fell in love with the neighborhood.
You know, the people there, the properties, everything about it.
One thing they noticed, kids never seemed to do homework.
When they asked why, most kids said they didn't have anyone to help them.
That got Joe Killinger thinking about how he got through school in rural Nebraska.
And it was just a situation where when I would get home and I was doing my homework, I could pick up the phone and call my math teacher - Francis Kohler sat on the phone with me hours every night.
You know, it just was I think a very integral part of my growing up.
I just saw this as a way to offer that.
Killinger is white and Pino is Asian.
They spend so much time in the neighborhood that they're sometimes mistaken for undercover cops.
They say another secret to their success is they evict tenants who break the law, do drugs or don't pay rent.
Chelsea Downs' dad, Carl Thomas(ph), says the center has made a huge difference.
It's like somebody sat a building here and took the other one away.
Before, it was much more louder.
And, you know, it was more destructive and stuff like that.
But right now it's more quiet.
You know, you can sit and you can watch your TV and not hear a bunch of noise outside but except kids.
And you know that the kids is playing and they feel safe.
At the UCLA School of Education, Professor John Rogers says he admires Pino and Killinger's initiative.
But he says private tutoring programs are no substitute for publicly funded efforts that are available to every child.

Now if you're relying upon your apartment as your access point for education and your family has to move, then you're losing out not just on your apartment but you're losing out on this key factor that's supporting your educational success.

is off limits for now because buildings are too expensive.
